sections.title: Medicare Basics
sections.content: Medicare Part A covers hospital care and is usually premium-free if you've paid payroll taxes. Part B covers outpatient services and has a monthly premium based on income. Part D covers prescription drugs. Part C (Medicare Advantage) bundles services with private insurers, often including dental and vision. Enrollment windows matterâ€”missing them triggers penalties.

points.title: Medigap Plans
points.description: Standardized policies that fill cost-sharing gaps in Original Medicare (Parts A & B). Monthly premiums vary by age and location.

points.title: Medicare Advantage
points.description: Combines hospital, medical, and often drug coverage. Lower premiums but restricted provider networks and potential copays.

points.title: IRMAA
points.description: Income-Related Monthly Adjustment Amount adds surcharges to Parts B & D if modified adjusted gross income exceeds set thresholds.

sections.title: Cost Snapshot
sections.content: Fidelity estimates a 65-year-old couple retiring in 2025 will spend about $350,000 on healthcare during retirement, excluding long-term care.

sections.title: Long-Term Care Planning
sections.content: Medicare does not cover extended custodial care. Evaluate hybrid life insurance policies, traditional long-term care insurance, or self-funding through earmarked savings. Planning early keeps premiums lower and broadens your coverage options.

sections.title: Healthcare Checklist
steps: Estimate annual Medicare Part B and D premiums using your current income.
Compare at least two Medigap and two Medicare Advantage plans in your zip code using Medicare.gov.
Project out-of-pocket costs (deductibles, copays, dental) in your retirement budget.
Research long-term care insurance options and note premium ranges versus self-funding.
Set a reminder to review coverage during the annual open enrollment period (Oct 15-Dec 7).

sections.title: Use HSAs Strategically
sections.content: Contribute the maximum to a Health Savings Account (HSA) while eligible and invest the funds. Withdraw tax-free for qualified medical expenses in retirement.
